Gameplay elements: 7/10: There are many things you can grab and use as weapons in this game: pistols, pans, cups, daggers, cleavers, and a few more on top of that. A note about suicide

A number of people are giving low reviews to this game because of its depiction of suicide and/or their inability to get past one of these moments in the game. This review is meant to help people who are thinking about buying this game but have reservations about the suicide in it, and/or to inform people about that suicide being in the game.

Zeroth: The following review contains very minor spoilers.

First: You can turn these segments of the game off in the settings you can go into as the game loads. Do so if you need to. These segments of the game are very infrequent and turning them off will not harm your enjoyment of the game or reduce the amount of content you get.

Second: While it is a questionable stylistic choice to include these segments, it is in keeping with the overall theme the game has. It isn't just a casual relationship with suicide, it is part of the reality of what you are doing in the game. In fact, they aren't even really suicides if you stop and think about what's actually happening in the story. As to if that is better or worse, you'll have to decide.

Third: The game is absolutely amazing. If you've ever wanted to feel like an action film star without having to be one, this is the game for you. It is a puzzle game. Every encounter can be solved by clearly and methodically thinking your way through what you are seeing. You don't need to move quickly, twitch skills actively work against success. Stay calm. Stay centered. Be aware of your surroundings. There simply is no better experience in VR, even in 2020 as I write this.

Fourth: The graphics are minimalist. If you are looking at the preview video, that's what you get. There is no hidden amazing section of high graphical fidelity. If that's all you care about, skip this game. Your loss, though.

joeshmo_raiders13May 8 at 7:21 PM
1st VR experience-Mind blown

This was the very first game I purchased and played on my very first VR headset - the Quest. I chose this game because I had played the xbox one version of it already and had a ton of fun playing on the xbox. I really wasn't sure what to expect with this being my very first VR experience but my friend and I decided to jump in and see what virtual reality was all about.

Let me tell you...there are very few times in my life that have been more exhilarating than cutting bullets in half mid-air with blades or dodging them in slow-mo as they graze past my face in Super Hot. Whoever saw this game on console platform and decided to figure out how to bring it to VR is a freakin GENIUS (I'm pretty sure that's the correct chronological order of this game anyways).

As I've seen a few other reviews say, this is indeed an action/puzzle type game. Fast-twitch movements may feel necessary at first due to blades and bullets constantly flying at you, but this actually hurts more than it helps. Utilizing the slow motion/time-stopping ability to see what moves you need to make next is paramount to success here (there's a bullet flying at my head so I need to dodge that...but by the time I do that red guy will have fired again. But slightly to my left is a gun a previous bad guy dropped when I killed him...so by leaning left I can pick that gun up and simultaneously dodge the incoming bullet while being ready for the next one). And that's just one scenario off the top of my head!

One minor issue with this game is replay ability. Don't get me wrong I've beat the story mode 3 times and done each of the Endless maps probably 20 times a piece trying to beat my previous high scores. The problem is you'll notice that the bad guys spawn in pretty much the same spots every time so repetition can start to wear on you a bit. But now worries...just set the game down for the night and the next day it will be just as fun in my experience!

*Slight spoiler but also important to note*

I've also seen many complaints about the "suicide theme" in the game. I understand where these people are coming from. But looking at it that way is a very shallow perspective in my opinion. It's not an encouragement of the idea of killing yourself...rather the computer system in the story begins to "infect" your mind and try to persuade you to "free your mind by destroying your bodily form which is enslaving the abilities of your mind" Yes it may still sound like a suicidal theme...but it's very clear that's not at all the intent if you pay attention to the story itself.

After all...Mind Is Software

Almost perfection, with one MAJOR flaw.

I love this game immensely, don't get me wrong. I find myself flinching in real life and trying to find new ways to finish each level, and feeling like an absolute GOD while controlling time. It is an absolute 5 star game, but the VR experience itself on Quest, in my opinion, is a 3-4 star one. The issue I ran into is a very annoying one, and almost experience breaking. I'll try my best to describe it.

When you finish a scene, and it moves you to the next one, it treats wherever you're standing at the transition as the centre of your play zone. You could be at the very edge of your guardian boundary and it would automatically reset your centre to where you are, meaning you're constantly reaching outside of it, even in a large space.

In the PCVR version, before each transition, you were required to walk back to your centre and grab the pyramid. This one does it automatically which you'd think would make the immersion better, but it actually costs it a lot when you're constantly having to move back to your centre on your own, either using pass through or by peaking out under the headset, and recentring by holding the oculus button, almost every single transition (especially if you're in a smaller play space.)

If this was fixed, it would be 100% 5 stars and I would recommend everyone to buy it without hesitation. However, because of this experience breaking bug, I'd have to warn people first, and straight up not recommend it for Quest users in a small space.

noam.gordonDec 24 at 1:08 AM
Ingenious!

This is a perfect example of how far a clever and original idea coming from a low-budget indie house can go, providing a better gaming experience than many big and flashy but boring AAA titles.
Sure, the graphics and story are pretty minimalist, but in a good artistic way, and I totally dig the design (although I wouldn't mind a little more "outside VR helmet" footage and more story). The game is totally focused on its core idea of slowed-time action, and is very effective at that.
Somehow, regrettably, I skipped the original non-VR game, but playing this VR title I really feel it is the perfect match. Superhot VR is one of the best and most effective uses of VR, and VR is the best platform for Superhot. So much so, that I actually feel less interested in playing the original non-VR title now. IMO, the developers should re-issue the original title in VR, with movement using the thumb joysticks.
I have just finished the game and I do feel it was a little short (but still satisfyingly intensive). Good thing there are these alt modes now (Endless, Headshot, etc). Let's see if I have the guts to try them...
Anyway, to sum up, it's a must buy. Period. Well done.

Enjoyment well worth the price tag

GAMEPLAY

Pros:
- Dynamic physical puzzles are action-orientated and thoughtful
- Makes you feel like an in-matrix superhero
- Substantial endgame (endless waves, speedruns, modifiers, etc.)

Cons:
- Due to limited weapon types, combat can feel a bit samey after a while. Not noticeable until significantly beyond the main campaign however


STORY

Pros:
- Surprisingly immersive VR-within-a-VR narrative
- Interesting dark and cultish feel

Cons:
- Lacking in real depth and clarity


VISUALS

Pros:
- Stylistically beautiful
- Little touches (e.g. post-teleport seeing the aftermath of where you were before) present throughout

Cons:
- Somewhat basic, but this stops shy of exposing the Quest's technical limitations


LONGEVITY

Main story: 3-6 hours
All content: 40+


OVERALL

Enjoyment well worth the price tag. If you want engaging physical puzzles that will make you feel like Neo, you have a casual Saturday's or an intense week's worth of that here for your money. It's popular for a reason.

Six2sevenGMay 6 at 10:33 AM
A VR Masterpiece

The original console version is one of my favorite games. The core mechanics are simple yet the way you are tasked in the game makes it difficult and complex, yet completely fair. Though, even with this being said, the game was not perfect. It was just missing something that was unobtainable due simply to the system the game was for.
VR gave the game what it was missing. While the devs could have pretty easily treated this the way Fallout 4 and Skyrim were (that being how they were just ported into VR), they built a new game from the ground up, while keeping the exact same wonderful feel of playing Superhot by keeping the aforementioned mechanics. This could easily be considered a full fledged sequel, rather than just it being known as "Superhot VR". By giving you the base mechanics of this game but also the ability to move as if you were your character, it pushes the game to its peak. Instead of moving a thumbstick to the left to just move out of the way of bullets, you actually dodge said bullets. This alone is one of the most amazing parts of the game, because it really puts you into the world. I found myself trying to kick enemies and then realizing that's not possible. The game draws you in with its simple mechanics and gun play, and then once you're there, hits you with the complex presentation, similar to how they did in the first game, but it is instantaneously better because of one simple reason-It's in VR.
In conclusion, Superhot VR is one of the most enjoyable games I've played in a very long time. Whether you have played the original or not, get this one. You won't regret it.

ClipzardFeb 24 at 11:10 AM
Fantastic Shooter Experience

I had previously played this game on my Xbox, so I was expecting a similar experience but I was quite surprised.

For the price of not being able to walk around much, being able to move your body to take cover, aim your shots, epically & cinematically dodge bullets whilst pretending to be Neo and breaking a sweat most certainly makes up for it. As my first shooter experience in VR, I can say that SUPERHOT would easily receive 5 stars from me if it wasnt for the few issues I experienced.

Sometimes the hit detection on myself and enemies seemed off, not consistently but enough to be noticeable. I could fire at an enemy and miss but the bullet would go past them closely and still be considered a hit. This could be considered as the game being forgiving but I am very observant and would always look to make sure I hit the enemy which is why I noticed this and found it slightly jarring. The same went with enemies firing at you, sometimes you would feel as though you were definitely not gonna be hit but still were which could be quite frustrating at times. Very minor but I feel as though its important for me to mention.

I often felt disoriented when the next scene of a level was loaded as all it takes to position you is where you are looking, to counter this I made sure to quickly look in the most comfortable position in my play area just before the next scene triggered. This could be just because of my situation with a smaller play area.

Despite the extra modes offered after completion, the game feels pretty short for the price tag but I may feel this way only because I had previously played the game.

Lastly, the story felt very underdeveloped due to the length of the game but still likely understandable to most who play if you pay attention to all the messages the game conveys.

Besides these gripes, I can wholeheartedly recommend this gem of a VR experience, I wont spoil much here but Id like to mention to anyone looking to purchase the game...that you very much should, no matter your previous experience with shooters!

High intensity workout

I might just be unfit, but Super Hot gets me, well, Super Hot. Despite its time-moves-as-you-do mechanic, it's very intense, forcing you to duck, stand, bob, weave, punch and throw. Honestly a really fun, solid, experience and a must-have on the quest for both your enjoyment and others. Also greatly improved by the quest being untethered.

Run into a major issue with a larger rectangular play area resulting in the game placing objects (weapons, next level pyrimids) outside of my reach and spawning me in the wrong location (in a table/barrier, outside an elevator). The fix was to simply designate a smaller, square start area - but - I would really like to see an improvement here - perhaps a option to recenter on death and the ability to do snap/smooth turning? More minor issue is that hitboxes seem a little oversized and underdetailed (ie. no holes)

I don't think those issues are a huge hamper on gameplay however, as you'll learn to avoid/fix them pretty quick. Just make sure you keep a margin around your guardian, I've definitely punched a wall by accident!

WiseScryerNov 25 at 10:43 AM
What can I say? There is nothing like it

Concept is simple.

You are dropped into the middle of an action scenario, usually surrounded by bad guys.

Time stops when you stop, time moves when you move, this lets you dodge bullets, punches, make impossible shots, and is the core concept of the game. This is what makes you feel like Neo.

Use Pistols, Uzis, Shotguns, bottles, combat knives, cleavers, ash trays, billiard balls, cameras, ninja stars, mind powers and calculators to eliminate your enemies until none remain.

And thats about it. I shudder to think of what would happen if a strong, overt narrative was placed over such insane mechanics. This could change the game.

Tips For Playing

1. Use a big space, you will be ducking behind barrels, crawling under office desks, peaking around pool tables, and maneuvering within store fronts and pizza shop kitchen, your gonna need the space.

2. Block bullets with objects to save yourself. Some objects break, others don't, and others still do a little better than just block, but I'll let you discover that part. Point is, block with stuff you pick up, it will save your life.

3. When you've run out of bullets, bottles, knives, and other stuff to throw, do not forget to resort to your Mind Powers, if you have progressed far enough in the game to get them. I would forget this all the time and lose matches I could have easily won.

And thats it, figure the rest out yourself, you'll love it!

Must Have Title With a Few Big Flaws

First of all, this game is a must buy for the Quest if you have a big play area. The wireless 6DoF combined with the time show mechanic creates a beautiful shooter that I'd play for hours; "wish" being the key word, because the campaign for this game is absurdly short. With 1-2 hours of play time depending on your skill level, it feels as if just when you get hooked the story ends. This shortened playtime is especially apparent when you compare it to the PC version of the game, which has a more fleshed out story, and gives the game room to grow.
The second flaw is the menu. You only unlock the option to do anything other than the main story after you beat the game, and then the menu is extremely confusing once you get to it.
My third problem with the game is the level design. By keeping the player mainly stationary with the exception of dodging bullets, it's time slow mechanic is underutilized compared to the base game, which has you actually moving through the levels.
All in all, this game on the Quest is a downgrade from the base non-VR game, but a major upgrade from any other VR version of it. A couple little additional downsides are sprinkled here and there, including the baffling absence of the body swap mechanic, replaced by an insta kill button, and a couple other little things. A must buy, but not the absolute masterpiece it's hailed as.

Will test your flexibility and space...

Smooth performances and several satisfying combat scenarios cannot quite make up for Superhot VR's faults. I heavily would not recommend this games to players with little space to move, as many sequences are genuinely impossible without having to quickly move three feet in any given direction. And I mean any given direction, including down, as you will find yourself surrounded by so many bullets to dodge you feel more like your taking a Yoga class than moving like John Wick, and it does not help that bullets fired by you are often inaccurate against moving targets, ensuring you rarely ever get headshots from far away, or any shot on the enemy on the first shot at all. Speaking of accuracy, throwing stuff makes you feel like your hands are blindfolded, as I have found that no matter how straight my angle was, the gun/knife/ashtray I threw would always just miss the enemy by hitting the ground/ceiling/air near him. This is frustrating when the game puts you in sequences where you have no guns and have to throw stuff, forcing to wait for gun-weilding enemies to get close enough for you not to miss, which often ends in very dumb deaths. And I found most of my deaths to be dumb, as I would be killed by bullets that I could swore just passed me, bullets that gained an abrupt burst of speed towards my face just from turning around to face it, bullets that went through some pieces of cover to hit me, and bullets that surrounded me with absolutely no hope of me doing an upward dog to dodge it, usually at the last set-piece before a checkpoint, forcing me to do that upward dog again.

If you loved Superhot VR on PC or PSVR, this will be a dream port that's worth the money to buy it again, without risk of tearing your teather into several pieces.
